data.title: Bluesin' musin'
data.text:
Barbara Ann Heyer 11.30.1931 – 5.8.2023

Barbara Ann Heyer, 91, passed away May 8, 2023. She was born on November 30, 1931, in Allen Park, Michigan to Anthony Flaishans and Gertrude (Dasher) Flaishans. Barbara married the love of her life, Ralph Eugene Heyer, on March 27, 1954, in Allen Park, Michigan. June 49 graduate of Lincoln Park HS. Trombone player in the Marching Band. She will be remembered as a loving, devoted wife, beloved mother, dear aunt, and faithful friend. Barbara was a fabulous shopper in both clothing and markets. She excelled in baking, cooking, gardening, and flowers, word puzzles, while maintaining a wonderful home atmosphere. After her son, Brent, entered elementary school, Barbara was an excellent office manager for the S.S. Kresge Company, which evolved into the Kmart Corporation. Her weekly hair salon visits were a must. Barbara was a terrific swing dancer esp. the Driving Blues to tunes like (Going to Kansas City/Sweet Home Chicago). She was affiliated with the Detroit Blues Society for several decades. Instead of going to the High School Prom, Barbara and boyfriend, Ralph, went downtown (Detroit) to the long defunct Flame Show Bar on John R and East Canfield to rock to the sounds of the T-Bone Walker Band. The couple danced on many cruises and ballrooms. My dear darling, save your long-time dance partner a small spot on Heaven’s dance floor.

https://www.detroitnews.com/obituaries/det123276

There are blues music lovers all over the world. Some are casual about it, others are very ardent blues lovers. And people express their love of blues in many ways. But I doubt that anyone has been as intent on pursuing their love of blues – and of dancing to the blues – for as long (over 70 years) as Detroit area couple – Barb and Ralph Heyer. Sadly, with Barb’s passing, their historic run at helping keep the blues alive has been truncated. Barb will truly be missed on the Detroit blues scene, though I do believe that her participation in the blues community will stay alive in our hearts and memories. Our sincere condolences to Ralph and family, and to all who knew Barb.

A couple of years ago I interviewed Barb and Ralph for the Detroit Blues Society’s Blues Notes newsletter. Here is that piece:

Blues Lovers Extraordinaire – They Just Gotta Dance

I don’t recall when or where I first saw this couple (dancing). It had to have been at a Blues music event. At some point I noticed that they were (dancing) at almost every Blues event I attended. I started taking pictures of them (dancing). And got to know them a little bit. Finally, I just had to find out about all that (dancing). So, I got them to stop (dancing) long enough to answer some questions. Here’s some of what they had to say. – Don Mc Ghee

It was 1947. Two teenagers from Lincoln Park went to Detroit’s Fox Theater on a date. It would be the first time they experienced a live musical performance. The attraction – a young dancing, singing, drumming Sammy Davis Jr, with the Will Mastin Trio. They were wowed! It would turn out to be the first of hundreds of times they would find their way to bars, lounges, halls, show bars, supper clubs, outdoor concerts, music festivals and cruise ships, to hear the music they loved – and, to DANCE! Blues, R & B, Motown and some jazz drew them in. For more than 70 years they’ve been to countless Detroit and southeastern Michigan venues and they’ve caught top acts in Las Vegas, Memphis and Florida. Their names – Ralph and Barb. Both are now 89 years old; Ralph will be 90 in June. Early on they were often drawn to Detroit venues like the Flame Show Bar, the Frolic Supper Club and the Garfield Lounge because those places featured the music they loved.

They celebrated their June, 1949 graduation from Lincoln Park High School, by going to The Flame (even though the legal drinking age was 21), where they saw T-Bone Walker. “Nobody bothered us, they didn’t question our age,” says Ralph. “T-Bone would play the guitar behind his back, do the splits, playing and singing all the time. He never missed a beat!” (The Flame featured top national African American entertainers. 1949-1963) Barb and Ralph “would go down to The Flame [John R and E. Canfield] on a Friday/Saturday night. It was a mixed crowd and always pretty crowded, but we could still dance some.” It became a favorite. They recall seeing Bull Moose Jackson (a singer & saxophonist out of Cleveland who performed jump blues and had a reputation for bawdy songs like “I Want a Bowlegged Woman”). Ralph adds, “Johnnie Ray used to come around and sing, we liked him a lot.”

The Frolic Show Bar, on John R, was another semi-regular stop in those early days, where they’d see John Lee Hooker. Barb remembers seeing “Wild Bill” Davison, a trumpet player out of Ohio. “They had a lot of different acts there. It was really good music, and we could dance.” Then, across the street to the Garfield Lounge. “But they smoked that funny stuff inside there, so we only went once,” said Ralph. “We would move around a lot. We went to a lot of different places–anywhere there was good Blues or R & B music, and where we could dance,” says Barb, “including the Willis Show Bar.” (Willis and Third Ave jazz bar, 1946-1978)

Early on Barb and Ralph got together with 4 other young married couples and hired a private dance instructor. They met every week at someone’s house for the lessons. As soon as the lesson was over, they would all go out to a club to practice what they had just learned. About a year after the lessons ended, “the other four couples were all divorced,” says Ralph. “We stuck it out.” They have been married for 67 years. Might the dancing be the ticket?

When asked about their love of music and dancing, both give energetic responses. Barb – “We started dancing more in the 60s.” Ralph – “Dancing gives you energy, it just uplifts you, you feel that beat and you just have to start moving. And it relaxes you.” Barb – ” that’s right, you’ve got to start moving when you hear the beat. Music makes you feel happy, good about everything.”

Favorite kind of music and dancing? Ralph: “We can dance to different kinds of music, different steps, but we really like swing dancing. We like that driving Blues music so you can get out there and really swing.” He adds that they also like half time. Neither sings or plays an instrument now, but Barb played trombone in the Lincoln Park H.S. marching band. She performed in the Thanksgiving Day parade and at Thanksgivings Day Detroit Lions games.

More Barb & Ralph dancing at: https://www.bluesphotosbydonmcghee.com/Private/n-pb2pz/BARBRALPH/

In spite of a life filled with dancing, they never entered a dance competition. “We dance for ourselves, for our own enjoyment,” says Barb. “And with the dancing, there was always something to look forward to. And you meet a lot of great people.” Ralph – “Oh yah, We’ve met some real nice people, black & white – Blues enthusiasts, vocalists, dancers. We used to always see Sweet Claudette – talk to her, have a drink. She was really a nice person.” Barb – “We used to hit all the clubs. A lot of them are closed now.” Ralph reflects on Memphis Smoke in Royal Oak: “We used to have some really good times there — a lot of wild times.” (Memphis Smoke featured blues music for many years, 1994-2010)

Barb and Ralph are Detroit (and national) music-loving heroes to me! For over 70 years, from the time they were very young, throughout a very long and active life, they have been strong supporters of many places and musicians that make up our strong musical heritage. Ralph and Barb are a kind of walking, talking (dancing) living history of an important part of the Detroit area music scene – its venues and its artists. Blues in particular:

Chef Chris and His Nairobi Trio (winners of the 2002 IBC band competition) in Ann Arbor

Rev. Robert Jones at the Monroe County Library Black History Concerts

Joe Weaver, Lady Sunshine, Thornetta Davis at Top of the Park in Ann Arbor

Johnnie Bassett and Thornetta at Jazzin’ on Jefferson.

Robert Penn at the casino

Betty Lavette at the Music Menu

Alberta Adams at lots of different places

The Butler Twins at the Greektown Festival & other places

Billy Davis in a park in Lathrup Village and wherever he performed

Peter “Madcat” Ruth at The Ark in Ann Arbor, and in Milford and many other places

At a DBS Blues Challenge event at Dearborn’s Teeny Street Roadhouse Ralph and Barb became DBS members, and have been proud members ever since. Blues Notes is how they learn of Blues music events. And, they go EVERYWHERE! If it’s Blues, with room to dance, Barb and Ralph are going to be there, swinging! I’ve seen them at: John’s Carpet House, on the grass and broken concrete, in Detroit; the DBS Heritage Series at Detroit’s Scarab Club; DBS Blues Challenge events at various locations; Memphis Smoke, Callahan’s, Hastings Street Ballroom, WHFR radio fundraisers [New Place Lounge], Token Lounge, the Plymouth Elks Club Blues series, the Antifreeze Blues Festival, as well as festivals in Oxford, Alpena, Jackson, Kalamazoo and Lansing. They danced on a grassy hill at the Cowpie Blues Festival, outside of Alaska, MI (and didn’t step in any cowpies. I did!) There are many other places where I wasn’t, and they were – dancing, for sure! Including on a catamaran in the Caribbean!

In addition to trips to Florida, Las Vegas, Memphis, and tours to Europe and other places, Ralph and Barb take cruises – and they… dance! On a cruise to Bermuda, a band really captured their fancy. “We asked them to play “Kansas City” – we really swing to that,” Ralph recalls. “For the rest of the cruise, any time we would be anywhere near the dance floor, no matter what they were playing, the band would stop and swing into Kansas City, and Barb and I would go out on the floor and start swinging.”

In Mexico on a day-trip catamaran cruise: “Everybody was partying down, drinking and dancing. When the boat docked, we hit a night club with a young couple from Denver. The entertainment was a Michael Jackson impersonator. Somehow, after the act, Barb was dancing with “Michael” and I was dancing with his lady. Then Barb was dancing with the Denver guy and I was dancing with his wife. In between, I was dancing heavy with Barb, when lo and behold, in walk 5 beautiful college girls. One of them asked Barb, ‘do you mind if I dance with your husband?’ Barb says no, go ahead. So I swung with her. Then a second girl came up and and then another. Before long, I had to dance with all 5. And I’m fighting a cold. They left, and here come 5 more. And I had to dance with 4 of them. One didn’t dance. Whew! that was OK with me, because my nose was running, and I’m blowing my nose and getting beat up. But we had one hell of a ball. That was probably by far my roughest evening on a dance floor.” My sympathy to Ralph for having suffered such a terrible ordeal.

Ralph says Doug Wolgat, with the Bluescasters, always liked their dancing “so, he and his wife went out and took a few dance lessons. Now we see them out dancing at different places.” Ralph says his brother was a good dancer, “but if anybody was on the floor dancing a little better than him, he’d sit down. Wouldn’t dance any more. Hell, I never sat down. I watched those really good dancers — I might learn something.” Ralph says that “Barb always had a lot of good moves, and always looked good. She’s still got some moves, but she’s not using them much anymore.” When I asked Ralph if there was anything else he could tell me about all those years with Barb and Blues music and dancing. His response, “We never fell!”

This is one of my favorite photos (from among the 25,000 or so photos on my website). As a photographer, I love her tatoos and think this image really highlights, both her tatoos and the power and grace of her music. Incidently, her right arm has a tatoo of a woman playing a violin. (her?) Rebecca is half of a duo known as the Nouveaux Honkies. The other half is Tim O’Donnell, who plays guitar and sings, and writes many of their song. They sometimes add drums, and/or a bass or a steel guitar and become a full band.

I was able to catch the Nouveaux Honkies at a bunch of different places along Florida’s Atlantic Coast, from Palm Beach to Fort Pierce, during the years I spent January/February on Hutchinson Island. Sometimes they were a duo, sometimes a 4-piece band. I think one of the things that originally attracted me to them was the blues that was in their music. I grew to enjoy them more as I discovered that there was so much more than Blues in there. They performed in an easygoing, sometimes folksy, but always unique, way – I was hooked! They were one of my favorite bands during those years. I believe I caught them not all that long after they began playing as the Nouveaux Honkies.

I saw them at Chef John’s (unfortunately no longer open), in Jupiter in early February 2011. They were playing with Eddie Kirkland, “The Gypsy of the Blues.” It was a great night of music! In earlier years, Tim had been a part of the backup band Kirkland had often used in the past, when playing in that part of Florida. (Unfortunately Kirkland was killed a couple of weeks later, February 27 on a highway in Homousassa, FL, when his car was hit by a Greyhound bus. (Eddie Kirkland was a storied bluesman. Watch for a separate blog with my captures of him, and stories from people who knew him.)

Music started in church for both Rebecca and Tim. She played in the school band, and majored in classical music, playing violin at the University of South Carolina. After playing there for a while she moved to Port Salerno, Florida (a small commercial fishing town). That’s where Tim grew up. Tim started on drums, moved to guitar, and played with several bands, off and on for several years. He says the reason he loves to play “is because it beats hot tar roofing in July.” They met at a local jam, and began playing together – The Nouveaux Honkies were born, and they gradually became popular throughout South Florida. Then for eight or so years they lived in a rebuilt RV and began touring much of the country. Tim says they are now “bi-statual”splitting their time between homes in Knoxville and Port Salerno, in south Florida.

It’s a little hard for me to describe their music – a mix of genres, songs with great stories (written by Tim) sometimes humorous, sung lightheartedly by Rebecca, always tight musically. Rebecca is a warm, always smiling performer, who really seems to have fun while she’s fiddling and singing. She really engages with the audience. Both are great musicians. They often play to, and off, each other, sometimes when doing light-hearted songs like “Big Heart, Hard Head,” and “You’re the Reason Our Kids Are Ugly.” Maybe I should let Tim describe their music – “mother lovin’, country folkin’, blues.” Or perhaps a writer for the Ft. Lauderdale Sun Sentinel, says it best – “If Johnny Cash and Freddy King had a baby it would be the Nouveaux Honkies.”

Whatever it is, I love their music and I love photographing them while performing. Rebecca’s ever-present smile and animated performing style elevates the “music for your eyes.” I’m glad Rebecca moved from South Carolina, and certainly agree with Tim – It’s good that he gave up roofing, in July, or any other time.

I haven’t seen the Nouveaux Honkies for five years now, but, as of this posting, Nouveaux Honkies are currently playing South Florida venues, including regularly at Gettin’ Crabby and Pirates Cove in Port Salerano, and weekly at Terra Fermata, in Stuart,

Plenty of tunes on YouTube, including, this on their 5th CD – “Loud In Here.”: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mFxX-fYABKY

This image is based on a photo taken at the Attic Bar in Hamtramck (a small city surrounded by Detroit) MI, in 2004. It is one of my very first attempts at using software to digitally alter a photograph. And it is one of my favorites. I think it shows Uncle Jessie White in a dignified way, which I believe is well deserved. Uncle Jessie White is a true Detroit legend. While a humble man, I see him as larger than life (as depicted), a giant and respected man on Detroit’s Blues scene.

Uncle Jessie White was born in Terry, Mississippi on September 24, 1920, and he died in Detroit January 29th, 2008. He began playing music when he was 9, a harp, and played off and on until he was about 20 years old, when he stopped music completely. He had a hard life. He began picking cotton when he was 5- years-old, plowed with a mule, worked in a saw mill and in gambling houses. He left it all that when his parents died, moving to Detroit in 1950. In Detroit he made his living as a junkman, collecting discarded items, scraps of all kinds from neighborhoods and wherever else he found it, then sold it to scrap yards.

An excellent documentary – “Uncle Jessie White: Portrait of a Delta Blues Man in Detroit,” 20 years in the making, provides a very personal insight into the life and music of Uncle Jessie. (see link below)

He began playing music again in the 1960’s when Detroit’s Butler Twins (Clarence and Curtis), began coming around playing music. That seems to be the beginning of what developed into Uncle Jessie’s famed weekend-long jams. His house on 29th Street became a place where local musicians came to play music, and young ones came to learn. Uncle Jessie played piano and harmonica, and he sang. The music continued all-night, off and on, from Friday night thru Sunday night. I hear that some people stayed until time to get back to work at the factories on Monday morning. Sometimes well-known musicians in town for a gig would stop by Uncle Jessie’s house jam. There are many stories about those weekends at Uncle Jessie’s house.

Later he had a regular weekly gig at the Attic Bar for about 20 years, until it was sold in 2007. The Attic Bar was really like a Blues joint – nothing fancy, just the Blues. It featured most of the local Blues bands, several nights every week. While he played in other places around town – the Attic Bar was perfect for him. I believe the bar got its name from all the “antique” items scattered on shelves near the ceiling – things that might well have come from grandma’s attic.

One unique thing about Uncle Jessie was his “rig.” It hung around his neck, and held a microphone and his harmonica, leaving his hands free to play the piano. Over the years there were several different versions of the rig. All were made from an incredible array of salvaged materials he gathered while “junking.” One used what appeared to be the handle of a lawn mower to hang the rig around his neck. Another used clamps from car battery charger cables to hold his harmonica to the rig. Then, a bent piece of copper tubing to hold the rig away from his chest. And what seemed to be the plastic bottom of a milk crate, or the wire bottom of shopping cart, as the base of the collection of repurposed items. It looked uncomfortable, but did serve its purpose.

The piano at the Attic Bar that Uncle Jessie used is also unique. The stains on the white keys on the left are said to be dried blood from his his fingers, dry and cracked from age. The missing paint and scratches on the board at the back of the keys come from the way he played the piano – often sort of clawing at the keys, rather than the playing in the style that a symphony concert pianist might play.

Uncle Jessie White was a kind and gentle man, with a wry sense of humor – he once described an incident in a gambling joint when a woman who stabbed him in his arm back in the 1930s in Mississippi. He said she was “the stabbingest woman I ever seen.”* I have heard that he used to play the guitar before that, but the injury to his arm forced him to abandon the guitar. A true Delta blues musician, he was sometimes called Detroit’s Godfather of the Blues, because of his influence on the Detroit Blues scene. He encouraged young musicians, allowed them to sit in, and mentored them in other ways.

Uncle Jessie had a profound influence on many Detroit area musicians. Plenty are still playing the Blues because of his mentoring. I produce a monthly live music concert series, Jazz & Blues at the Southfield (MI) library, and was fortunate to book him and his 29th Street Band during the very first year of the series (2005). I never got to know Uncle Jessie very well but I always enjoyed his down-home Blues, and love him for the valuable contributions he made to the music of Detroit.

*Very interesting article about Uncle Jessie’s life: https://www.thecountryblues.com/dr-barry-lee-pearson/uncle-jessie-whites-story-and-stories/

See more images of Uncle Jessie White, his rigs and performances here: https://www.bluesphotosbydonmcghee.com/Events/UJW/

Last Years at the Attic Bar (2003-2007), here: https://www.bluesphotosbydonmcghee.com/MidwestArtists/LASTATTIC/

Uncle Jessie White & 29th Street Band play “Bad Luck Child”: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7va88MzzUvc

A documentary – “Uncle Jessie White: Portrait of a Delta Bluesman in Detroit” is available on Youtube at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CVoDSuWnYGo
